Dear Emily,

It’s wonderful to hear from you, and I’m glad to support your journey toward publishing your work.

Below are some initial pointers and resources that should help you get started:

1. Clarify your publishing goals
   • Decide whether you aim for a peer-reviewed journal article, a book chapter, or a monograph—each has its own timeline and expectations.

2. Identify appropriate venues
   • Compile a shortlist of journals or presses whose recent publications align with your topic and methodology.
   • Review their “Aims and Scope” pages and recent issues to confirm a good fit.
   • Note word-count limits, citation style, and review turnaround times.

3. Tailor your manuscript
   • Position your argument within current scholarship and make explicit what is new about your contribution.
   • Ensure the introduction clearly signals the article’s intervention and roadmap.
   • Follow the target venue’s style guide meticulously (e.g., MLA, Chicago).

4. Prepare a strong cover letter or proposal
   • Briefly state the article’s central claim, why it suits the journal/press, and any special features (e.g., images, translations).
   • Keep it concise—editors appreciate clarity.

5. Mind the submission guidelines
   • For instance, Fairmont Publishing Group (see the shared notes) asks for a detailed proposal, a short summary, and the full manuscript in Word format. Most presses have comparable requirements—always double-check before sending.

6. Build in time for revision
   • Peer review can take several months. Use the waiting period to develop the next project or to refine conference papers into additional articles.

7. Helpful resources
   • Wendy Belcher, "Writing Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks"
   • MLA "Publishing in Journals" guidelines
   • Chronicle of Higher Education advice columns on publishing

Next steps
If you’d like, send me a short abstract (about 250 words) of your current project, and I can suggest suitable journals and framing strategies.

Please feel free to reach out with any questions as you move forward. I look forward to seeing your work enter the conversation.

Warm regards,
John
